Award.AwardTitle: Support for Doctoral Students from U.S. Universities to Attend AIED 2017 and/or EDM 2017

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The United States has historically been the global leader in the field of artificial intelligence in education (AIED), or ways to use computerized artificial intelligence to enhance teaching and learning in contexts ranging from children learning math in school, to soldiers learning highly technical jobs in the US military. The preeminent conference in this field is the AIED conference; at this conference the latest research is presented and practitioners learn the state of the art techniques that allow creation of these important educational technologies. A related conference that is equally significant is the Educational Data Mining (EDM) conference, which focuses on research on big data and analytics for education.

This proposal would provide partial travel support for 20 Ph.D. students, selected through a competitive process, to attend either or both of the AIED or EDM conference, present their work, and receive additional mentoring outside of their dissertation committees as part of a doctoral consortium. The intellectual merit of the work rests on the studies the graduate students submit to be considered for participation in the early career track of the conference; this work is then enhanced by guidance from world-class mentors who meet with the students in a structured format to improve their research. The broader impact includes the career impact on the twenty selected students, especially since promising graduate students whose advisors may not have funding to send them to the conference can still be included, and their work can be showcased and improved. Possible long-term broader impacts include building the field of artificial intelligence in education and data analytics researchers and thus eventually, improving the quality of education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 19th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Education (AIED 2018) is a top-tier research conference that brings together researchers in computer science, human-computer interaction, educational psychology, cognitive psychology, and education, to discuss issues related to intelligent technology-based support of learning activities. In 2018, AIED was held in London, UK, from June 25-30, and was co-located as part of the Festival of Learning with two other conferences, ICLS (the International Conference of the Learning Sciences) and Learning@Scale. All three conferences help to advance the vision of the Cyberlearning and Future Technologies program by examining how people learn in technology-enhanced environments, and how these environments can be designed to best support learning. AIED in particular focuses on building new technologies and leveraging these technologies to test theories of learning sciences.

This project provided 9 PhD students with travel stipends to participate in AIED 2018, which was held in London, UK, from June 25-30. All students presented their research at the conference, received feedback on their work, connected with other researchers, and wrote a 2-page reflection on their experiences. By attending AIED, these students also had the opportunity to participate in other Festival of Learning activities.

Attending conferences is difficult and expensive for students. Funding provided to doctoral students as a result of this proposal allowed them to become involved in the AIED conference. Students benefitted from conference activities, which foster academic and professional exchanges of ideas, theories, experiments, techniques, applications, and evaluations related to intelligent learning environments. As a result of their conference participation, students may have become motivated and inspired to become a part of the AIED communities. They additionally received access to various AIED resources provided to its members. The PhD students' research was likely positively affected by their participation in AIED and the exchange of ideas with the other Festival of Learning participants, and thus this project likely had an indirect beneficial effect on the overall quality of research in the AIED community.
